questions.text: An 8-year-old male child presents with fever and tenderness in the right lower limb. The limb is warm to the touch, and ESR is raised. An X-ray reveals periosteal elevation as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fever, localized warmth, raised ESR, and periosteal elevation on X-ray are classic indicators of acute osteomyelitis.

  • Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone, commonly caused by pyogenic bacteria in children.
  • The metaphysis of long bones is the usual site due to its rich vascular supply and sluggish blood flow, which predisposes to bacterial seeding.
  • Clinically, it presents with fever, localized pain, warmth, tenderness, and systemic signs of infection.
  • Raised ESR and CRP are common laboratory findings. On radiography, periosteal elevation appears by 7-10 days due to subperiosteal abscess formation.
  • Early radiographs may be normal, so MRI is more sensitive in the early phase (within 24 hours) as it can detect bone marrow edema.
  • Confirmation of diagnosis is through aspiration and culture of the infected site.

Explanation of other options:

Ewing sarcoma (Option A):

  • A malignant small round cell tumor seen in children and adolescents
  • Presents with fever, pain, and swelling but is less likely to show acute signs of infection like warmth and raised ESR early.
  • Onion-skin periosteal reaction is more characteristic.

Osteosarcoma (Option B):

  • Malignant bone tumor of adolescence
  • Typically presents with pain and swelling.
  • X-ray shows sunburst appearance and Codman's triangle-not just simple periosteal elevation.

Giant Cell Tumor (Option D):

  • Benign, locally aggressive tumor seen in skeletally mature individuals (usually after closure of epiphyses)
  • Rare in children and not associated with fever or signs of infection.

questions.text: A patient with prolonged intubation complained of respiratory distress. Which of the following staging systems is used to stage the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Cotton-Meyer classificationis used for staging post-intubation tracheal stenosis, which can develop due to prolonged intubation, leading to respiratory distress.
  • This classification helps assess the severity of tracheal injury and stenosis caused by mechanical ventilation.

Cotton-Meyer Classification of Subglottic Stenosis

  • Used to classify subglottic stenosisbased on cross-sectional airway obstruction.
  • Originally developed for pediatric patients,but now applied to adults.
  • Can be supplemented with letters (a-d)based on the number of laryngeal subsites involved.
  • Severe comorbiditiesor congenital abnormalities are marked with a '+' sign.
  • Idiopathic laryngotracheal stenosis (iLTS)commonly presents as Grade I-II stenosis.
  • iSGS (idiopathic subglottic stenosis)often occurs in women and presents with a higher grade of stenosis.

Explanation for other options:

Radkowski classification (Option B): Incorrect because the Radkowski = JNA staging (not tracheal)

TNM classification (Option C): Incorrect because TNM is a staging system used for cancers (such as lung cancer) and does not apply to respiratory issues caused by prolonged intubation.

AJCC classification (Option D): Incorrect because the AJCC classification is primarily used for cancer staging and does not apply to conditions like tracheal stenosis caused by intubation.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7139051/
  2. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8892813/

questions.text: What does the marked region in the given spirometry represent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked region in the given spirometry represents the Functional Residual Capacity (FRC).

  • Spirometrymeasures airflow in and out of the lungs, which is useful in diagnosing and monitoring lung diseases.
  • FRC is the lung air volume after a normal, passive exhalation. It is calculated as the sum of the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) and the Residual Volume (RV) and is around 2.3 L

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with migratory arthritis, and examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur. An echocardiography was performed, which was suggestive of mitral regurgitation. A biopsy specimen was obtained, and the image is provided below. What is the most likely lesion shown in the histopathology slide?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Aschoff's bodies are characteristic histopathological findings in Rheumatic fever.
  • The given clinical scenario of migratory arthritis, pan-systolic murmur, and mitral regurgitation, along with the characteristic granulomatous lesions, point to Rheumatic heart disease caused by Rheumatic fever.

Explanation for Incorrect options:

Epithelioid granuloma (Option B) is a characteristic feature of tuberculosis and other granulomatous diseases (like sarcoidosis). These granulomas are not typically seen in rheumatic fever.

Granulomatous vasculitis (Option C) refers to a condition where there is inflammation of the blood vessels, and granulomas form in the vessel walls. This is typically seen in diseases like Wegener's granulomatosis or Takayasu arteritis, not rheumatic fever.

Granuloma inguinale (Option D) is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It causes ulcerative lesions in the genital area.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 3-year-old boy who has presented with cognitive impairment and difficulty in mobility, along with the provided fundoscopy image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The cherry-red spot on the retina, along with the symptoms of cognitive impairment and difficulty in mobility, strongly suggests Tay-Sachs disease
  • It is a lysosomal storage disorder that causes progressive neurodegeneration in young children.

Conditions with Cherry-red spot:

  • Metabolic storage diseases:
    • Causes pathological accumulation of lipid-based material in various tissues.
    • The spot becomes less evident with time and there is optic atrophy.
      They are:
      • GM1 gangliosidosis
      • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
      • GM2 gangliosidosis: Tay-Sachs disease (Option A) and Sandhoff disease
      • Niemann-Pick disease: three types A-C
        • Type A and B present with a cherry-red spot
        • Type C presents with ocular motility issues
      • Farber disease
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion:
    • Retinal clouding from edema
    • Acute sign
  • Retinotoxicity:
    • Quinine
    • Dapsone
    • Gentamicin
    • Carbon monoxide
    • Methanol
  • Commotio retinae:
    • Edema due to blunt trauma
  • Miscellaneous:
    • Conditions giving a dark or reddish central macular appearance
    • Ex: Macular hole

Explanation for Incorrect Options:

Hunter disease (Option B) is a lysosomal storage disorder that leads to progressive cognitive decline, coarse facial features, and other systemic issues, but it does not typically present with a cherry-red spot on fundoscopy. It is also X-linked, affecting males more severely.

Hurler syndrome (Option C) is also a lysosomal storage disorder (mucopolysaccharidosis type I) and can cause cognitive impairment, coarse facial features, and skeletal abnormalities, but it does not typically show the cherry-red spot on fundoscopy. It also presents with corneal clouding and gargoylism (a characteristic feature).

Gaucher disease (Option D) involves the accumulation of glucocerebroside in various organs, particularly the spleen, liver, and bone marrow. It can lead to skeletal issues, hepatosplenomegaly, and anemia, but it does not typically cause cognitive impairment early or show the cherry-red spot on fundoscopy.

questions.text: On post-mortem, the dead body shows characteristic findings as depicted in the image. What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Smothering involves obstruction of the nose and mouth, usually without specific injuries to the neck.
  • Bruises or abrasions on the face may be present but are not localised to the neck.

Explanation for other options:

Hanging (Option A): Hanging typically shows an oblique, non-continuous ligature mark on the neck, located higher up (above the thyroid cartilage). There is usually no evidence of external injuries like bruises or fingernail marks around the neck.

Throttling (Option B): Throttling refers to manual strangulation. The findings often include bruising, abrasions, or fingernail marks on the neck, which are characteristic of a physical struggle. There may also be petechial haemorrhages in the eyes and other areas due to venous congestion.

questions.text: A jeep driver presented with pain in the gluteal region along with swelling. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pilonidal sinus is a chronic inflammatory condition in the natal cleft, especially in people with prolonged sitting habits (e.g., drivers), presenting with pain and swelling near the gluteal area.

  • Pilonidal sinus occurs in the sacrococcygeal region, typically in young, hirsute males who spend long periods sitting (like jeep or truck drivers).
  • The condition involves in growth of hair into the skin, causing a sinus tract or abscess formation.
  • Key Features:
    • Location: Midline over the sacrum or coccyx, in the natal cleft
    • Symptoms: Pain, swelling, discharge (sometimes foul-smelling), and intermittent abscesses
    • Risk Factors: Prolonged sitting, poor hygiene, obesity, coarse body hair
    • Diagnosis: Clinical based on symptoms and local findings
  • Treatment:
    • Acute abscess: Incision and drainage
    • Chronic/recurrent: Surgical excision (midline or off-midline closures like Bascom or Karydakis procedure)
    • Pilonidal sinus excision and repair by rhomboid flap

Explanation of other options:

Fistula in ano (Option B): Involves a tract between the anal canal and perianal skin, presenting with discharge near the anus, not in the upper gluteal region.

Fissure in ano (Option C): A painful tear in the anal mucosa, causes sharp pain during defecation and fresh bleeding, but not gluteal swelling.

Gluteal abscess (Option D): While this can present similarly with gluteal swelling and pain, it usually arises from infection or trauma and lacks the typical midline sinus tract or chronic features of a pilonidal sinus.

questions.text: A 35 year old obese female with hirsutism presents with lesions as shown. She is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hirsutism, obesity, and resistant lower face acne suggest hyperandrogenism as the underlying etiology.

  • This woman presents with acne that is not responding to isotretinoin or antibiotics, suggesting that the etiology may not be purely inflammatory or bacterial.
  • The combination of obesity, hirsutism, and acne localized to the lower face (U-zone) is highly indicative of hormonal acne, often driven by hyperandrogenism.
  • Evaluation of hyperandrogenism involves measuring serum testosterone, DHEAS, and sometimes 17-hydroxyprogesterone, to rule out conditions such as polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), late-onset congenital adrenal hyperplasia, or rare androgen-secreting tumors.
  • Hyperandrogenism leads to increased sebaceous gland activity and comedogenesis, often resulting in treatment-resistant acne.
  • Identifying the hormonal basis allows for targeted treatment with anti-androgens like spironolactone or oral contraceptives.

Explanation of other options:

Look for antibiotic resistance (Option A): Antibiotic resistance is a concern in acne management but is unlikely here as the underlying issue is hormonal rather than infectious.

Look for triggering drugs (Option B): Drug-induced acne is typically monomorphic and not associated with hirsutism or obesity; it's less likely in this clinical context.

Look for dietary triggers (Option C): Diet may exacerbate acne but does not explain hirsutism and obesity, which point to a hormonal etiology.

questions.text: A patient who was on steroids for the treatment of chronic urticaria presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of respiratory symptoms. He says that he has been having a nocturnal cough for the last several weeks. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen following bronchoscopy showed the presence of certain larvae as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The parasitic nematode Strongyloides stercoralis, which causes strongyloidiasis, has a larval form that can be identified in a bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) sample.
  • The patient's use of chronic steroids is a key factor because it induces immunosuppression, a condition that can precipitate the dissemination of the parasite.
  • While Strongyloides stercoralis infection is usually chronic and mild, immunosuppression from steroid therapy can cause it to escalate.
  • This widespread dissemination results in symptoms such as respiratory distress and eosinophilia, aligning with the patient's acute respiratory decline, nocturnal cough, and high eosinophil count.
  • The presence of respiratory symptoms is explained by the parasite's life cycle, where larvae migrate through the lungs before they are coughed up and subsequently swallowed.

Clinical features:

  • Effect of Migrating Larvae
    • Asymptomatic Infection: Over 50% may be asymptomatic.
    • Rashes: Recurrent maculopapular or urticarial rashes on buttocks, perineum, and thighs.
    • Cutaneous Larva Migrans: Serpiginous rash (larva currens) advancing up to 10 cm/hour.
    • Pulmonary Symptoms: Rare, mainly in chronic obstructive lung disease.
  • Effects of Adult Worms & Filariform Larvae
    • Mild to Moderate Load: Epigastric pain, nausea, diarrhea, constipation, and blood loss.
    • Heavy Larval Load: Risk of hyperinfection syndrome and disseminated strongyloidiasis.
  • Hyperinfection Syndrome
    • Cause: Repeated autoinfection leads to increased filariform larvae.
    • Risk Factors: Glucocorticoid therapy, immunosuppressive conditions, HTLV-1/HIV coinfection.
    • Features: Colitis, enteritis, malabsorption, possible progression to disseminated strongyloidiasis.
  • Disseminated Strongyloidiasis
    • Pathophysiology: Larvae invade GIT and other organs. Disrupted mucosa may allow enteric flora to cause bacterial sepsis, pneumonia, or meningitis.
    • Clinical Manifestations: CNS invasion, brain abscesses, meningitis; larvae in CSF. Eosinophilia, often absent in severe cases.
    • Mortality Rate: Nearing 100% untreated; over 25% even with treatment.

Investigations:

  • Stool Microscopy: Rhabditiform larvae; requires multiple samples (4+) for accurate diagnosis.
  • Microscopy of Other Specimens: Entero-test for duodenal aspirates; high filariform larvae are found in stool, sputum, and tissue biopsies for disseminated cases.
  • Stool Culture: Differentiates rhabditiform from hookworm larvae.
  • Serology: ELISA for antibodies; may show cross-reactivity, less effective for recent infections.
  • Coproantigen Detection: Antigen capture ELISA specific to Strongyloides.
  • Molecular Diagnosis: Real-time PCR targeting specific genes.

Treatment:

  • Asymptomatic Treatment: Strongyloidiasis should be treated regardless of symptoms due to the risk of hyperinfection.
  • Ivermectin (200 μg/kg daily for 2 days)

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Ancylostoma caninum (Option A):

  • This is a hookworm primarily affecting dogs, though it can occasionally infect humans through contact with contaminated soil.
  • However, it is less likely to cause eosinophilic pneumonia or produce larvae detectable in a BAL

Capillaria philippinensis (Option B):

  • This parasite is responsible for intestinal capillariasis, primarily affecting the intestines and causing symptoms such as diarrhea and abdominal pain, rather than causing respiratory symptoms or eosinophilia associated with respiratory issues.
  • It does not typically involve larvae in the BAL.

Enterobius vermicularis (Option D):

  • This is the cause of pinworm infections, which are generally not associated with eosinophilia or respiratory symptoms.
  • The larvae of Enterobius vermicularis do not typically appear in BAL specimens, as it is primarily an intestinal parasite.

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) specimen of a patient is shown below, along with microscopy. The report shows mononuclear cytosis, elevated proteins, and low sugars. What is the likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario, along with CSF findings of mononuclear cytosis, elevated proteins, low sugars, and the characteristic cobweb-like clot, strongly suggests tuberculous meningitis (TBM).

Features of Tuberculous Meningitis (TBM):

  • Etiology:
    • The infection is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
    • The bacteria reach the meninges either through the bloodstream or from the rupture of small tuberculous lesions (subependymal tubercles) located near the brain's ventricles.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • The disease typically has a subacute onset.
    • Symptoms include fever, headache, neck stiffness, and cranial nerve impairments.
    • Cranial nerve palsies, particularly of the nerves controlling eye movement, are frequent and result from the characteristic inflammation at the base of the brain.
  • Potential Complications:
    • Serious complications can arise, including hydrocephalus , elevated intracranial pressure, and cerebral infarcts.
  • CSF Analysis:
    • Cell Count: Predominance of lymphocytes.
    • Protein: Markedly elevated levels.
    • Glucose: Low levels (hypoglycorrhachia).
    • Clot Formation: A visible, cobweb-like film (pellicle) may form when the CSF is allowed to stand.

Diagnosis:

  • Gold Standard: CSF culture for Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Supportive Tests:
    • Acid-fast bacilli (AFB) stain.
    • PCR for tuberculosis.
    • CSF ADA levels.

Management:

  • Patient is started on ATT.
  • Systemic steroids to reduce inflammation.

CSF Findings in Different Types of Meningitis

Explanation for Incorrect options:

Chemical meningitis (Option D):

  • This occurs due to the rupture of tumor contents (e.g., from a dermoid cyst or glioma) into the CSF.
  • CSF Findings: Variable inflammatory response, often with elevated proteins but no infective organisms.

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on the clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reaction, light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • 3 is the right choice since the effects depicted involve the Trigeminal nerve ophthalmic division (V1), which supplies sensation to the forehead, scalp, and eye.
  • The Trigeminal nerve (5th cranial nerve) has three divisions:
    • Ophthalmic (V1)
    • Maxillary (V2)
    • Mandibular (V3)

questions.text: Which neonatal anomaly is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Exstrophy bladder is a congenital anomaly where the bladder mucosa is exposed outside the abdominal wall due to failure of mesodermal migration.

  • Bladder exstrophy results from a failure of mesoderm to migrate and form the lower abdominal wall, leading to a defect through which the posterior bladder wall protrudes and is visible externally.
  • It typically presents in neonates with the bladder mucosa exposed, downwardly displaced umbilicus, widely separated pubic symphysis, and epispadias.
  • In males, dorsal chordee and shortened penis are seen.
  • In females, there is bifid clitoris and wide labial separation.
  • If left untreated, patients suffer from complete urinary incontinence and are at increased risk for bladder adenocarcinoma.
  • This condition is easily distinguishable from other anterior abdominal wall defects due to visible bladder mucosa, absence of a herniated bowel sac, and association with genital anomalies.

Explanation of other options:

Omphalocele (Option A): Presents as herniation of abdominal contents into the base of the umbilical cord, covered by a translucent sac. The umbilical cord inserts into the sac-not seen in exstrophy.

Gastroschisis (Option B): Abdominal wall defect lateral to the umbilicus, with free-floating bowel loops that lack a covering sac-distinct from bladder mucosa exposure.

Patent vitello intestinal duct (Option C): Persistent communication between the intestine and umbilicus, may present as a fistula, sinus, or cyst near the umbilicus-does not show an exposed bladder.

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the image
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A nasopharyngeal airway (NPA) is a flexible, soft rubber or plastic tube inserted through the nostril into the nasopharynx to maintain airway patency in patients with obstructed breathing.
  • It is commonly used in semi-conscious or unconscious patients when an oropharyngeal airway is not suitable.

Explanation for other options:

Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA) (Option B): It is incorrect because an LMA is inserted into the pharynx and forms a seal over the laryngeal inlet, unlike an NPA, which is placed through the nose.

NG Tube (Option C): It is incorrect because a nasogastric tube is used for feeding or decompression of the stomach, not for airway management.

Oropharyngeal tube (Option D): It is incorrect because an oropharyngeal airway is inserted through the mouth, while the given device is inserted through the nose.

questions.text: Identify the type of hymen shown in the image below
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image is indicative of a septate hymen.
  • This condition is identified by the presence of a band of hymenal tissue that creates a bridge, resulting in two distinct lateral openings.
  • Embryologically, the hymen is a membranous remnant formed at the junction of the sinovaginal bulbs and the urogenital sinus. Typically, this membrane perforates before birth to create a single vaginal opening.
  • A septate hymen results from the incomplete perforation of this embryonic tissue.

questions.text: A 12-week-old child presented with fever, cyanosis, and fatigue. His chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The X-ray reveals a "figure-of-eight" or "snowman" appearance, which is characteristic of supracardiac TAPVC.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option B): Associated with "boot-shaped heart" on X-ray.

Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA) (Option C): Associated with "egg on a string" appearance on X-ray.

Pericardial Effusion (Option D): Would present with an enlarged, globular heart ("water bottle" appearance) on X-ray

Reference: Partial and Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)
